Graphical abstract Polymer supports play an important role in noble metal loaded catalysts. In this study, palladium clusters stabilized by several polyamides have been widely studied in the oxidation of benzyl alcohol under airflow. The different kinds of polyamides (PADs) were synthesized with aromatic diamines and trimesoyl chloride by mechanical grinding method and solvent-heat method. Polyamide support was synthesized through mechanical grinding method. And the laminar structure and abundant amide bonds of polyamide can help obtain ultrafine Pd clusters with a mean particle size of 1.76 nm. The Pd0.5@PAD-2-M effectively catalyzed benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde with a conversion of 96.1 % and turnover number (TON) of 1441 under 90 °C in water which was 2.5 times higher than the commercial Pd/C catalyst. High TON value of 6505 was also achieved in solvent-free system. This work reveals the advantages of laminar structure of polyamide in dispersing Pd clusters and promoting benzyl alcohol conversion. Besides, the carrier properties of amphipathy and substrate adsorption were also investigated to illustrate the significance of interfacial effect for laminar catalyst in heterogeneous catalysis. Keywords Benzyl alcohol oxidation Polyamide Palladium clusters Nanocatalyst Laminar material 1 Introduction The selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde is an important organic transformation in pharmaceutical and chemical industries for the utility of products as crucial drug intermediates and fine chemicals [1,2]. Homogeneous catalysis, photocatalysis and thermal catalysis are widely studied reaction systems [3–5]. From the viewpoints of atom economy and environmental concern, developing noble metal heterogeneous catalysts and using water as green solvent or solvent-free under atmospheric pressure prevail as an attractive green technology [6–8]. In the recent years, a multitude of highly efficient conversions of benzyl alcohol on noble metal catalysts were reported. While excellent TON values are usually acquired in the limiting conditions or with an extremely low metal loading amount [9,10]. Usually, highly effective noble metal loaded catalysts cannot resist recycling tests for severe reaction conditions. They usually encounter falling off from support or aggregating during the reaction resulting in a decrease with activity. The design of noble catalysts with high efficiency and stability is in demand under the mild conditions. Among the reported noble metal (Au, Pt, and Pd) loaded catalysts [11–14], Pd-based catalysts are used widely for their high-efficiency in the selective oxidation of alcohols [15,16]. And the activity of Pd species can be adjusted through the characteristic parameters including particle size, particle distribution and surface state which are regarded to be affected by the support [17,18]. In order to achieve the requirements towards high performance and stability of Pd clusters loaded catalysts, it is essential to design new materials as functional supports to enhance the catalyst activity and stability in the oxidation of benzyl alcohol. Functional supports are worth discussing in-depth as well as the support metal strong interaction (SMSI) for different catalysis applications [19,20]. Because the weak surface force between metal and carrier can keep the metal active, but cannot guarantee its stability. While too strong surface force can stabilize metal but often leads to a deactivation of activity. In particular, the design of support is closely linked with noble metal active surface [21]. On the one hand, support can affect the surface free energy, particle size, electronic state, dispersion, and stability of Pd clusters [22,23]. On the other hand, the interaction between support and the reaction substrates would influence the mass transfer process, the reaction rate and even determine the product selectivity in the reactions [24,25]. Various kinds of supports have been developed to immobilize Pd clusters, including metal organic framework (MOFs) [26,27], covalent organic framework (COFs), metal oxide [28], zeolites [29], and reduced grapheme (RGO) [30]. The specific surface area, channel structure, surface properties, and functional groups of above supports were illustrated to be effective for dispersing and stabilizing Pd clusters [18,31]. While the Pd clusters loaded catalysts still suffer from contradictions for that too strong interactions between functional groups and Pd clusters may aggravate the aggregation and too weak interaction may not prevent Pd clusters falling off from the carrier in heterogeneous catalysis. Therein, functional groups (like carboxyl and amino groups) coordination is an important way for catalyst carriers acting on Pd clusters [32,33]. Polyamide is just a functional polymer that combines the advantage of carboxyl and amino groups for that is prepared by amidation reaction of carboxyl monomer (or chloride monomer) and amino monomer [34]. Common synthesis methods include solvent synthesis [35], mechanochemical synthesis [36], and post-functional group conversion methods (oxidation of imine linkage into more stable amide bond) [37,38]. Due to the resistance of polyamide materials to acid, alkali, heat, and organic solvent, it is widely used as membrane materials and applied in the selective adsorption and separation of CO2 from N2 mixture [39,40]. The reported polyamide has been applied with diverse morphologies including spherical stack, laminar stack, and three-dimension frame [34]. The study of laminar polyamides is rather scarce than others. However, as a carrier of noble metals, laminar polyamides have the following advantages: 1) rich amide bonds can stabilize Pd clusters through N coordination [41], 2) laminar morphology and carbonyl in the linkage can promote the contact between substrate and support through the hydrogen binding force [42,43], 3) the tunable size of the synthesized monomers can control the density of amide bonds and thus the degree of aggregation of Pd clusters [44,45]. Thus, polyamides provide the opportunity to solve the loading knots of dispersion and stability by the adjustable amide bonds on a laminar surface, with a high efficiency in selective oxidation reactions. In this work, we report a novel method to stably anchor Pd clusters by plenty of amide linkages on laminar polyamide supports. Through the facile operation, two kinds of polyamides were synthesized with different densities of the amide bond and crystalline degree. After ultrasonic stripping, highly dispersed and ultrafine Pd clusters were loaded and reduced on the surface of laminar polyamide with an average particle size of 1.76 nm for Pd0.5@PAD-2-M and the catalysts were tested in the oxidation of benzyl alcohol under airflow. This typical catalyst exhibits superior activity using water as solvent, achieving a conversion of 96.1 % and selectivity of 99 % with a TON value of 1441 at 90 °C. In the solvent-free system, high TON value of 6505 was also achieved. The minimized energy calculation of optimized structures, kinetic analysis, and a series of characterization further illustrate the promotion of interfacial effect on Pd0.5@PAD-2-M. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Reagents All of the following chemicals were commercially available and used without further treatment: trimesoyl chloride (TMC, Aladdin Industrial Inc., 98 %), p-phenylenediamine (Aladdin Industrial Inc., >97 %), biphenyl diamine (Aladdin Industrial Inc., 98 %), sodium hydroxide (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., 98 %), sodium tetrachloropaladate (NaPdCl4, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., >98 %), sodium borohydride (NaBH4, Aladdin Industrial Inc., >98 %), benzyl alcohol (Aladdin Industrial Inc., 99.5 %), benzaldehyde (Aladdin Industrial Inc., 99 %), toluene (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., 99.5 %), naphthalene (Aladdin Industrial Inc., 98 %). 2.2 Method Attenuated total reflection-Fourier transform infrared spectra (ATR-FTIR) were performed on the Agilent Cary 660 instrument with the wavenumber from 4000 to 800 cm−1. Solid UV–vis spectra were measured with a Shimadzu UV 2600 spectrometer utilizing BaSO4 as the basal material. Solid state 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AVANCE-III spectrometer in magnetic field strength of 9.4 T corresponding to the Larimore frequency of 100 MHz for 13C nuclei at room temperature with a CP/MAS unit. X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) patterns were collected on a Smart Lab diffractometer from Rigaku equipped with a 9 kW rotating anode Cu source at 45 kV and 200 mA (5−90°, 0.2° s-1). Elemental analyses (EA) were carried out with a CHN elemental analyzer Vario EL cube. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis proceeded on a STA409 instrument in the dry N2 atmosphere (10 °C min−1). The wettability was assessed by testing the contact angles (CA) through the sessile water drop method on a DSA-100 contact angle goniometer under ambient conditions. Scanning electron microscopic (SEM) images were obtained on a Hitachi S-4800 field-emission scanning electron microscope. Nitrogen sorption experiments were performed at the temperature of liquid nitrogen (77 K) on a BELSORP-MAX analyser with the samples being degassed at 120 °C for 3 h before analysis. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis was carried out on a JEM-2100 (JEOL) electron microscope (200 KV). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were performed on a PHI 5000 Versa Probe X-ray photoelectron spectrometer equipped with Al Karadiation (1486.6 eV). Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP) was measured according to OPTMA 20000V. 2.3 Synthesis of polyamide support Laminar polyamide was prepared through mechanochemical grinding with aromatic amine monomer and 1,3,5-benzenetricarbonyl chloride (TMC) [36]. The specific synthesis process as follows: TMC (0.532 g, 2 mmol) and 1,4-phenylenediamine (0.325 g, 3 mmol) were added in the agate mortar at one time and then the mixture turned into yellow-green after grinding clockwise for about 15 min at room temperature. The photographs are displayed as in Fig. S1. After that, sodium hydroxide solution (NaOH 5 wt%, 10 mL) was added drop by drop in the mortar, then continued to grind for another 15 min. The mixture was washed with 50 mL mixed solvent of ethanol and water (v/v = 1/1) for about 5 h, and then the solid was separated by filtration, washed with deionized water, and dried in an oven at 50 °C for 12 h to obtain a yellow solid powder. Then yellow powder was stripped by ultrasound for 1 h in water to gain the laminar morphology which was named as polyamide-1-M (PAD-1-M). The support polyamide-2-M (PAD-2-M) was synthesized with the same procedures. It's just that the amino monomer has been replaced from 1,4-phenylenediamine (0.325 g, 3 mmol) to 4,4′-biphenyldiamine (0.552 g, 3 mmol). Besides mechanochemical method, solvent method was also applied in the synthesis of general powder packing polyamide (PAD-2-S). 2.4 Preparation of Pd@PADs catalyst The Pd clusters catalysts were prepared through dynamic adsorption and NaBH4 reduction route. Typically, aqueous solution with PAD-2-M (1.0 g) was mixed with 20 mL aqueous Na2PdCl4 (0.0138 g, 0.047 mmol) solution in a round bottom flask, and then stirred at room temperature for 12 h. After that, 10 mL sodium borohydride (0.01 g NaBH4) solution was added drop by drop at 5 °C for the reduction and then the mixture was stirred continuously for 12 h after ultrasonic operation for 20 min. The solid was separated by filtration, washed with water for three times, and then dried in an oven at 50 °C for 12 h to obtain about 0.6 g gray-black solid catalyst named as Pd0.5@PAD-2-M. Pd0.5@PAD-1-M and Pd0.5@PAD-2-S was also prepared with the same steps as above. Similarly, 20 mL aqueous Na2PdCl4 (0.0276 g, 0.094 mmol) solution and Na2PdCl4 (0.0552 g, 0.188 mmol) solution were added to the mixture of the carrier to synthesize Pd1.0@PAD-2-M and Pd2.0@PAD-2-M. 2.5 Catalyst evaluation The catalyst performance was evaluated by the oxidation of benzyl alcohol with airflow in water. The reaction was carried out in a reaction platform equipped with 20 mL reaction tubes and an air pump. Typically, benzyl alcohol, catalyst and water were successively added in a reaction tube and stirred at 90 °C for 24 h with fierce stirring. After the reaction, naphthalene (0.1 mmol) as the internal standard was used as the internal standard using ethanol (10 mL) as the dilution solvent in the reaction system, and then the catalyst was separated through a miniature high-speed freezing centrifuge. The product was analyzed by gas chromatography (GC, Fuli9700Ⅱ) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a capillary column (KB-1). Conversion of benzyl alcohol = mmol (benzyl alcohol converted) / mmol (initial benzyl alcohol) × 100 %. Selectivity of benzaldehyde = mmol (benzaldehyde produced) / mmol (benzyl alcohol converted) × 100 %. Besides, oxidation of benzyl alcohol with oxygen at a certain pressure was carried out in a 30 mL magnetically stirred autoclave (Anhui Kemi Machinery Technology Co., Ltd.). In a typical run, benzyl alcohol, catalyst, and water were added into the autoclave, which was pressurized to 1.0 MPa after charging and deflating three times. The autoclave was heated to 90 °C and kept for 1 h. After each run, the solid catalyst was separated by filtration, washed with ethanol for three times, dried in an oven at 50 °C for 12 h, and then charged into the next run. 2.6 Computational details The minimize energy calculation towards every item was conducted using the MM2 program with the properties of Pi bond orders and steric energy summary on Chem 3D software (Job type: minimize energy to the minimum RMS gradient of 0.010) [46]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization Scheme 1 outlines the synthetic route of PADs and corresponding supported Pd clusters. The synthesis involves four steps for: 1) synthesis of laminar polyamide by mechanochemical grinding, 2) ultrasonic dispersion of polyamide powder into laminar material, 3) the Pd precursor (NaPdCl4) loading by dynamic adsorption, 4) the reducing of Pd precursor to Pd clusters with NaBH4. The theoretical loading amounts of Pd were 0.5 wt%, 1.0 wt%, and 2.0 wt% for Pd0.5@PAD-2-M, Pd1.0@PAD-2-M, and Pd2.0@PAD-2-M, respectively. The complete catalyst synthesis diagrams reveal the composition and laminar framework structure of supports and catalysts in theory. Fig. 1 a shows the FTIR spectra of four samples, the peaks at 1660 cm−1 for the amide bond suggest successful polymerization of TMC and 1,4-phenylenediamine, which is consistent with the disappearance of the signal at 1743 cm−1 for TMC (Fig. S2) [47]. The additional characteristic peaks of amide bond at 1595, 1512, and 1320 cm−1 for bending vibration of NH, CN, and stretching vibration of CN, all prove the existence of amide bonds [48]. Besides, the signal at 3320 cm−1 for the stretching vibration of NH should have been a sharp peak, but it became wider owing to the water absorption [49]. Comparing the changes of two supports before and after loading metal, it can be found that the intensity of the signal at 3320 cm−1 was reduced indicating the existence of an interaction between N and Pd atoms. The polymer frameworks of PAD-1-M, PAD-2-M, and the two catalysts were further verified using solid state 13C NMR spectra (Fig. 1b and 1c). The chemical shift peak at around 25–40 ppm corresponds to the bits of the methylene unit attached to the benzene ring in the polymer terminal [50]. The strong signals at 120–125 and 125–140 ppm are ascribed to the carbon atoms in the benzene ring [51]. The carbon atoms in the amide group are reflected by the peak at 160–175 ppm [38]. For PAD-1-M and Pd0.5@PAD-1-M, only a broad peak around 22.5° was found in the XRD pattern (Fig. 1d). While the peak around 20−24° for PAD-2-M is wider than PAD-1-M [52]. In the low angle XRD patterns, new peaks appear at 7.5° and 5° for the two polyamides and there are two obvious characteristic peaks between 20−24° for PAD-2-M (Fig. S3). It does mean that both PAD-1-M and PAD-2-M are partly ordered materials and PAD-2 owns higher crystallinity [53]. In addition, the Pd0.5@PAD-1-M and Pd0.5@PAD-1-M maintain similar XRD patterns with their supports indicating that the Pd clusters may keep high dispersion on the two catalysts. The UV–vis spectrum of PAD-1-M shows higher adsorption intensity for more chromophores (amide bonds) than PAD-2-M (Fig. S4) which is consistent with the CHN element analysis as in Table 1 [54]. The TG curves show that PAD-1-M started to decompose from 400 °C with high thermal stability, and the decomposing process of PAD-2-M was divided into two-phase for 250–400 and > 400 °C due to the low polymerization degree and unpolymerized amino-group at the end of the material (Fig. S5). The above structure and composition representative confirmed the successful synthesis and stable property of polyamide supports. The N2 sorption isotherms exhibit the porosity of polyamides and catalysts. All of the four samples show the analogous type III sorption isotherms, indicating the accumulation of macrospores as showed in pore distribution (Fig. 2 ). The exact textural data are listed in Table 1. And low surface areas for 14, 9, 22, and 10 m2 g−1 are according to the property of laminar materials and abundant hydrogen bonds of polyamide [55]. Although there are just same macropores to promote the mass transfer, it should be noted that the laminar structure may provide a platform for catalytic active sites (Pd clusters) and substrate (benzyl alcohol) help enhance the catalytic activity instead of mesopores. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of PAD-1-M and PAD-2-M demonstrate the stacked morphology of laminar material, after the ultrasonic stripping, and the laminar structure looks more vivid (Fig. 3 a-3b) [56]. The TEM images of PAD-1-M and PAD-2-M further illustrate the flaky composition as in Fig. 3c-3f. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images demonstrate the formation of ultrafine and homogeneously dispersed Pd clusters (Fig. 4 ). The average particle size of Pd0.5@PAD-1-M is 1.69 nm, and the high-resolution TEM image displayed that the lattice distance is 0.2289 nm, which is consistent with the [111] lattice plane (Fig. 4a-4c) [57]. The particle size distribution of Pd0.5@PAD-2-M is narrower than Pd0.5@PAD-1-M and the mean particle size is 1.76 nm. While the lattice distance similar with Pd0.5@PAD-1-M indicating the same crystal faces exposed on the catalyst surface (Fig. 4d-4f) [58]. With the increasing of Pd loading amount, a little bigger average particle sizes for about 2 nm were happened on Pd1.0@PAD-2-M and Pd2.0@PAD-2-M (Fig. S6). To further confirm the surface state and the interactions between Pd clusters and amide bonds, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed on Pd0.5@PAD-1-M and Pd0.5@PAD-2-M (Fig. 5 ). The survey scan spectra of Pd0.5@PADs present four dominant peaks centred at 280.8, 335.6, 395.9, and 526.9 eV, corresponding to the presence of C 1s, Pd 3d, N 1s, and O 1s, respectively (Fig. 5a) [50]. The C 1s spectrum was resolved into three individual component peaks at 284.6, 285.4, and 288.0 eV, which are attributable to the CC, CN, and CO bonds, respectively (Fig. 5b and S7-S8) [59]. The N 1s peak of Pd0.5@PAD-1 with bonding energy of 400.1 eV is lower than the support PAD-1-M (400.2 eV). This phenomenon just also happened on Pd0.5@PAD-2-M and PAD-2-M indicating that there exists an interaction between N and Pd clusters (Fig. 5c) [60]. The O 1s peaks at 531.3 and 531.4 eV for Pd0.5@PAD-1-M and Pd0.5@PAD-2-M are consistent with PAD-1-M and PAD-2-M (Fig. 5d). [19] The shift happed on N 1s illustrating that the key role of amide bond lies on N atoms nor O atoms. Two sets of double peaks corresponding to Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 can be observed on Pd XPS spectra. The relatively lower binding energy set of a spin-orbit doublet at 336.4 (3d5/2) and 341.3 eV (3d3/2) is attributed to Pd(0) species, and the other set of a doublet at 337.9 (3d5/2) and 343.1 eV (3d3/2) is assigned to Pd(II) species for Pd0.5@PAD-1-M (Fig. 5e) [61]. Especially, the component at 336.1 eV in Pd0.5@PAD-2-M is assigned to Pd(0), which is slightly lower than that in Pd0.5@PAD-1-M for 336.4 eV indicating more active site exposure. The XPS characterization of Pd 3d spectra shows that only about 40 % Pd(II) were reduced to Pd(0) species after the reduction of sodium borohydride. Pd(0) was usually regarded as the major constituent in benzyl alcohol oxidation [12]. While a part of Pd(II) was always reserved in the reduced catalysts [5]. And the influence of Pd(0)/Pd(II) ratio was also researched on catalytic activity. Pd(II) shows an important function for activating oxygen in the reaction process [62,63]. So, although Pd(0) is the main catalytic active center, Pd(II) can also promote the reaction during the catalytic process by helping to activate oxygen. Pd(II) species were not completely reduced to Pd(0) species may duo to two reasons: (1) A part of Pd species on cluster surface was oxidized into PdO by O2 in the air because of the high activity of the surface Pd atoms [64]. (2) There are many Pd-N bonds generated during the loading process and the functional group have a strong traction for Pd atoms. Compared with previous researches, the proportion of Pd(II) in this work was indeed higher than the ideal result which may be related with the plenty of amide bonds and the laminar structure [65]. 3.2 Oxidation of benzyl alcohol Catalysts were all employed in the oxidation of benzyl alcohol under air condition (Table 2 ). Without Pd active sites, the substrate cannot be converted to benzaldehyde by using PAD-2-M as catalyst (Entry 1, Table 2). Pd0.5@PAD-1-M with a Pd loading amount of 0.47 wt% got a benzyl alcohol conversion of 88.5 %, while Pd0.5@PAD-2-M obtained higher conversion for 96.1 % under the same reaction conditions (Entries 2–3, Table 2). When the loading amount of Pd species was increased, the conversion decreased to 91.4 % and 82.1 % as for Pd1.0@PAD-2-M and Pd2.0@PAD-2-M. Especially for Pd2.0@PAD-2-M, there was more than 10 % reduction in benzyl alcohol conversion compared with Pd0.5@PAD-1-M. The reason for the unfavorable effect may be related to the size of the particles (Entries 4–5, Table 2). For support with non-laminar structure, Pd0.5@PAD-1-S showed a benzyl alcohol conversion of 80.3 % (Entry 6, Table 2). Commercial Pd/C with a Pd loading amount of 5 wt% only exhibits a moderate catalytic effect with 39.4 % conversion (Entry 7, Table 2) with an average particle size of 3.65 nm (Fig. S9). By comparing the above five catalysts, Pd0.5@PAD-2-M overmatched others and got the highest TON value for 1441 with a near complete conversion of benzyl alcohol. In the solvent-free system, a higher TON for 6505 was obtained under 150 °C. With 1 MPa O2 as oxygen resource, a benzyl alcohol conversion for 57.4 % was achieved for 1 h, and high TOF for 861 h−1 appeared (Entries 8–9, Table 2). The harshness of the reaction conditions was increased again, and the catalyst showed higher reaction performance with a benzyl alcohol conversion of 86.2 % under high temperature and pressure (Entry 10, Table 2). In order to further understand the catalytic behavior of Pd0.5@PAD-2-M in the benzyl alcohol oxidation reaction, the kinetic curves were performed (Fig. 6 a). In the initial stage, the reaction rate was fast and a half of the substrate was converted within 6 h. To obtain the accurate reaction rate, the kinetic curve of Pd0.5@PAD-2-M was fitted with a pseudo-first-order kinetic model at 90 °C which was calculated by linearly plotting ln(Ct/C0) versus time as the inserted picture in Fig. 6a. Pd0.5@PAD-2-M exhibited a high benzyl alcohol conversion rate constant of 0.1286 under airflow. Similarly, the kinetic curve of Pd0.5@PAD-1-M shows that 40 % benzyl alcohol was converted into benzaldehyde within 6 h (Fig. 6c). And the kinetic curves are fitted with a pseudo-first-order kinetic model. Reaction rates at 90 °C were calculated by linearly plotting ln(Ct/C0) versus time. Pd0.5@PAD-1-M exhibited a moderate benzyldehyde formation rate constant (k) of 0.08511 which is slower than Pd0.5@PAD-2-M (Fig. 6b and 6d). Besides, a serious of reaction optimizations were employed as in Table S1. In the initial 1 h, conversion of 15.1 % was obtained which brought the highest TOF for 227 h−1. When the reaction solvent was changed into toluene, 98.5 % conversion of benzyl alcohol was achieved, and this is similar to a water system. The reaction was also tested under different temperatures (Entries 3–5, Table S1). Under room temperature, only a conversion of 29.9 % was obtained. And if it was raised to 70 °C and 90 °C, 66.4 % and 96.1 % of conversions can be achieved. When the catalyst addition amount was reduced to half at 90 °C, the conversion only showed 30% loss. Abundant reaction data under different reaction conditions proved the high efficiency of Pd0.5@PAD-2-M. The non laminar catalyst Pd0.5@PAD-2-S was also tested in the heterogeneous oxidation to research the advantages of laminar property on the water-oil interface. PAD-2-S was synthesized through solvent method and SEM image shows that they are aggregations composed of small particles with the size ranging from several to hundreds of nanometers (Fig. S10). The Pd clusters show a uniform distribution with an average particle size of 1.98 nm which was similar with Pd0.5@PAD-2-M. While the catalytic effect was significantly lower than laminar catalysts and only a benzaldehyde yield of 80.3 % was realized with a formation rate constant (k) of 0.06764 (Fig. 6e). While the stability was still laudable and the catalytic activity after 5 runs is similar to that of fresh parts which be related to abundant of amide bonds (Fig. 6f). Catalysis stability for Pd0.5@PAD-1-M and Pd0.5@PAD-2-M were also investigated in a five-recycling test. After the first run of reaction, this catalyst that marked as re-Pd0.5@PAD-2-M was recovered by centrifugation and reused in the next run. There is no apparent decline in benzyl alcohol conversion reflecting the stable activity during the reuse process (Fig. 6b). The Pd amount of re-Pd0.5@PAD-2-M was also tested by ICP analysis with a content of 0.41 %, indicating that the reused catalyst is almost the same with fresh Pd0.5@PAD-2-M and the content of palladium in the filtrate is lower than the detection line. The stability test of Pd0.5@PAD-1-M with no loss of activity also confirmed the stabilization effect on Pd clusters by amide bonds (Fig. S11). In order to eliminate the false appearance of catalyst stability caused by excessive catalyst, the recycle test under a moderate conversion was performed, and the catalyst was still not deactivated after five runs (Fig. S12). Besides, catalytic stability under hard condition was also tested, the catalyst Pd0.5@PAD-2-M showed a benzyl alcohol conversion of 84.9 % with a selectivity of 92 % in the 5th run test, indicating a strong stability (Fig. S13). While the commercial Pd/C showed poor performance in cyclic multiplexing experiments, after 5 runs, benzyl alcohol conversion decreased to 34.1 % from 39.4 % (Fig. S14). FTIR spectra and XRD patterns of re-Pd0.5@PAD-1-M and re-Pd0.5@PAD-2-M exhibit the same signals with their fresher samples and demonstrate a stable catalyst structure during the reaction process (Figs. S15-S17). Further, the TEM image of reused catalyst re-Pd0.5@PAD-2-M was also tested (Fig. S18). It can be found that there are almost no particles gathering with a uniform particle size distribution. And the average particle size (1.82 nm) of Pd cluster was almost the same with that on fresh catalyst. The oxidation of benzyl alcohol was widely researched including homogeneous and heterogeneous systems, photocatalytic and thermal catalytic systems, solvent free or base free system, high temperature or room temperature system, etc (Table S3). Among them, homogeneous catalytic system can obtain a high conversion under very mild conditions, the non-recyclable property still limits the value of industrial applications [3,66]. Photocatalytic oxidation is energy-efficient and environment friendly, while most of photocatalytic systems need the organic solvent to realize a high catalytic efficiency [4,5]. Similarly, although non-noble metal and non-metal catalyst are more cheaper and widely available, organic solvents like n-heptane and dimethyl formamide (DMF) are usually necessary [24,67]. In the heterogeneous thermocatalytic system, noble metal based catalysts were widely studied than non-noble metal or non-metal catalyst for the excellent catalytic performance of noble metal atoms. All Au, Pd, Ru, and Pt based catalysts can realize a high benzyl alcohol conversion, while Pd based catalysts are preferred because of their higher cost performance [8,68,69]. High temperature or pressure can bring high activity and TON value (more than 100,000) for noble metal catalysts, while the stability cannot be guaranteed with high temperature and high pressure [1,7,70,71]. Atmospheric oxygen or air is more frequent and greener in aqueous catalysis systems [72]. Generally, high activity is hard to implement under mild reaction conditions, especially in solvent-free system [73,74]. Inorganic supports like molecular sieve, metal oxides and high-entropy oxides can provide a robust and stable structure for Pd particles, the adjustment of surface property and functional groups was challengeable [75,76]. Special supports should be designed which can not only disperse and stabilize Pd clusters, but also can ameliorate the contact between benzyl alcohol and active centers. Water is a green and nontoxic solvent, benefiting the product separation and high liquid O2 concentration. O2 balloon or O2 bubbling method is the usual way for supporting oxygen source, while air is more cheap and accessible. In this work, Pd0.5@PAD-2-M exhibited excellent catalytic activity in benzyl alcohol oxidation with water as solvent at a low temperature of 90 °C, exhibiting high conversion (96.1 %), selectivity (>99 %), TON value (1441), and well stability during the recycling tests. These above comparisons confirm that Pd clusters supported on polyamide servers as a robust and stable heterogeneous catalyst for low-temperature oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde with air. 3.3 Insight into the reaction With the same amide bond as linkage for PAD-1-M and PAD-2-M, the average particle size and surface state of Pd clusters are distinctly leading to different catalytic activities. The theoretical calculation was carried out to gain insight into the interaction between Pd atom and the constituent unit of two kinds of polyamides. The stabilization energy (SE) of Pd species by the repeating unit of the support (RUS) was calculated according to the following equation: SEPd+PAD = MTEPd+PAD - MTEPd - MTEPAD, in which MTEPd+PAD, MTEPd, and MTEPAD are the minimized total energy (MTE) of the Pd + PAD, Pd atom, and PAD, respectively. The exact MTE values are listed in Table S3. The stabilization energy for Pd with PAD-1 was -1.6941 kcal mol−1, and the optimized configuration represents a precise position for Pd atom (Fig. 7 a). The stabilization energy of Pd and PAD-2-M system was -1.9010 kcal mol−1, exhibiting a closer distance of 4.118 Å between Pd and N atoms (Fig. 7b). This indicates that PAD-2-M has a more significant stabilization effect on Pd atom. Besides, the contact angles of PAD-1-M and PAD-2-M were also tested for 85° and 70° indicating both amphiphilic properties in the reaction system (Fig. 7c). PAD-2-M shows more hydrophilic property than PAD-1-M and gets more exposure to oxygen in the reaction process which is the reason for that supports can promote catalytic activity. Through the comparison of different catalysts and different catalytic conditions, it was sure that both particle size, surface state of Pd clusters and amphiphilic properties have decisive influence on catalytic activity for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol. Compared with Pd/C, it can be found that the Pd clusters (smaller than 2 nm) on PADs have a more profound impact. As shown in Fig. 7d, the activities and the average particle size are negatively correlated in total, the larger particle sizes, the lower activities. While for Pd0.5@PAD-1-M and Pd0.5@PAD-2-M, the larger Pd clusters obtained higher conversion meaning that the surface state plays a leading part during the catalytic process. And for Pd0.5@PAD-2-M and Pd0.5@PAD-2-S, it can be found that the carrier with two-dimensional layered structure has better ability to disperse Pd species than that with spherical stacked structure. Herein, the laminar structure can provide a platform for catalytic active sites (Pd clusters) and substrate (benzyl alcohol) [7,77]. The open structure on both sides of the two-dimensional plane is beneficial to the mass transfer and can improve the catalytic reaction rate [78]. Interfacial modulation between Pd clusters and support can control the reaction microenvironment required by the active site [79]. The two-dimensional surface interacts with the metal through weak van der Waals force, so small molecules (O2) can catalyze the reaction through the confined space between the two-dimensional surface and the metal. The structured limiting space between laminar polyamide and Pd clusters provides an ideal limiting microenvironment both experimentally and theoretically. Another reason for higher catalytic effect of Pd0.5@PAD-2-M may be caused by the larger contact area on the water-oil interface [80]. As illustrated above, the amide bond in the catalytic carrier serves to disperse and stabilize the Pd clusters. Moreover, the H bond and laminar structure can also promote the adsorption and diffusion of the substrate. The carbonyl groups in the amide bond can adsorb benzyl alcohol through forming hydrogen bond between the oxygen atom and the hydroxyl group on the benzyl alcohol as the first step in Fig. 8 . This greatly promotes the rate and probability of contact between the substrate and the active center, because the active center of Pd clusters is also around the amide bond and interacts with the N atom. Even under the condition of airflow, Pd0.5@PAD-2-M can exert high conversion with a high TON number and remain stable in the 5th cycle. In fact, the catalyst is a catalytic reaction that occurs at the oil-water interface, because benzyl alcohol and water are incompatible, and the catalyst is amphiphilic. In the proposed catalytic cycle, the hydroxyl of benzyl alcohol combines with Pd to form a Pd-H bond, and at the same time, the hydroxyl group is interrupted by Pd to form an O-Pd-H transition state. Then, the H atom on the methylene is further attracted to Pd forming a Pd-H bond again, with the breakage of the Pd-O bond. In this way, benzaldehyde as the catalytic product is generated [12]. As the oxygen in the airflow activates the Pd-H bond, H and O atoms were converted into H2O2, which is finally decomposed into H2O and O2. A completed catalytic cycle is completed. 4 Conclusions The polyamide supports strongly modified the catalytic behavior of Pd clusters, and catalyst Pd0.5@PAD-2-M produced the highest conversion of benzyl alcohol of 96.1 % with a high TON number (1441) under mild conditions. Thus, the catalytic performance is significantly enhanced by the presence of N and O atoms in the amide bonds. The synergistic facilitation way of N (secondary amine groups) and O (carbonyl group) in amide bonds for Pd species and benzyl alcohol is the characteristic of this article, resulted in highly dispersed, stable, and efficient active centers for the catalyst. Moreover, the amphiphilic property of polyamide benefits the catalytic performance at the interface of the water and oil phase. This work constructs an efficient and stable heterogeneous Pd catalyst for the synthesis of benzaldehyde from benzyl alcohol, and provides a “bottom-up” strategy towards the synthesis of laminar polyamide by mechanochemical synthesis with acyl chloride and amino monomers for the preparation of highly dispersed and stable Pd clusters catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Polymer supports play an important role in noble metal loaded catalysts. In this study, palladium clusters stabilized by several polyamides have been widely studied in the oxidation of benzyl alcohol under airflow. The different kinds of polyamides (PADs) were synthesized with aromatic diamines and trimesoyl chloride by mechanical grinding method and solvent-heat method. Polyamide support was synthesized through mechanical grinding method. And the laminar structure and abundant amide bonds of polyamide can help obtain ultrafine Pd clusters with a mean particle size of 1.76 nm. The Pd0.5@PAD-2-M effectively catalyzed benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde with a conversion of 96.1 % and turnover number (TON) of 1441 under 90 °C in water which was 2.5 times higher than the commercial Pd/C catalyst. High TON value of 6505 was also achieved in solvent-free system. This work reveals the advantages of laminar structure of polyamide in dispersing Pd clusters and promoting benzyl alcohol conversion. Besides, the carrier properties of amphipathy and substrate adsorption were also investigated to illustrate the significance of interfacial effect for laminar catalyst in heterogeneous catalysis.
coredata.dc:title: Engineering ultrafine Pd clusters on laminar polyamide: A promising catalyst for benzyl alcohol oxidation under air in water
